title: 112_hr6412
content: The Act may be cited as the "Attracting the Best and Brightest Act of 2012" and provides immigrant visas for certain advanced STEM graduates. The "Attracting the Best and Brightest Act of 2012" provides immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates with a master's degree or higher from a US research institution in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics, with an offer of employment. Up to 50,000 visas are available for qualified immigrants in this category. The "Attracting the Best and Brightest Act of 2012" offers immigrant visas for advanced STEM graduates with a master's degree or higher from a US research institution in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics, with an offer of employment. Visa applicants must have an approved labor certification and receive a wage level equal to others in similar positions. The term 'United States research institution of higher education' refers to an institution in the US classified under the Department of Education's Classification of Instructional Programs in computer and information sciences, engineering, mathematics, and physical sciences. The National Science Foundation director must excel in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics, be established for at least 10 years, and not offer incentives for enrollment or financial aid based on success in recruitment or admission activities. The text chunk discusses amendments to visa regulations for nonimmigrant students and accreditation requirements for educational institutions. Amendments are made to visa regulations for nonimmigrant students and accreditation requirements for educational institutions. This includes changes to immigrant status procedures, labor certification, and qualifications for certain immigrants. This includes changes to immigrant status procedures, labor certification, and qualifications for certain immigrants. The amendment includes new criteria for individuals holding a doctorate degree in a STEM field from a US research institution of higher education. Amendments to visa regulations and accreditation requirements include new criteria for individuals with a doctorate in a STEM field. Applicants must submit a job order to the State workforce agency for the labor they seek to perform. The agency will post the job order on its website for 30 days. The Secretary of Labor will include links to State workforce agencies on the Department of Labor's website. Employers must demonstrate that compensation for foreign workers meets or exceeds a certain threshold to satisfy visa requirements. The Secretary of Labor requires employers to meet or exceed compensation levels for foreign workers to satisfy visa requirements. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the National Science Foundation's use of classification authority, and the Secretary of Homeland Security will provide public information on aliens granted status under a specific section. The amendments made by this section require employers to provide information on aliens granted status under a specific section, including employer details, number of aliens granted status, occupations sought, and effective date of the amendments. The amendments made by subsections (a) through (e) will be repealed after a 2-year period from the enactment of this Act. Student visa reform is addressed in Section 3 of the Act. Section 101(a)(15)(F)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to specify the requirements for an alien student to pursue a full course of study. Additionally, Section 214(b) of the Act is amended to clarify nonimmigrant status. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow qualified alien students to pursue studies in science, technology, engineering, or mathematics at higher education institutions. AGE-OUT PROTECTIONS FOR CHILDREN. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include rules for determining the age of a child in immigrant petitions and applications for adjustment of status. The age of the alien at the time of filing the petition is used to determine if they qualify as a child. The age of the alien at the time of filing the petition is used to determine eligibility for adjustment of status or an application under section 245(d). SEC. 5. PERMANENT PRIORITY DATES. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for family- or employment-based petitions. The priority date will be the date of filing the petition with the Secretary of Homeland Security or State, unless preceded by a labor certification filing with the Secretary of Labor. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to establish permanent priority dates for family- or employment-based petitions. Aliens who are beneficiaries of approvable petitions will retain the priority date for subsequent petitions. The amendment takes effect upon enactment and applies to pending classification petitions.
